pull.title: [devtools translations] catch invalid specifiers
pull.body:
While being careful in the source code, during translation a "%" can easily sneak init the wrong position, especially when dealing with percentages (how comes?). 
Instead of giving up, catching that can make life easier.

events.message:
catch exact exception ...

 ... and display the affected string

events.body: Why not just catching this error by linter? The error can be caught whenever someone open a PR.

<!--5d09a71f8925f3f132321140b44b946d-->The last travis run for this pull request was 241 days ago and is thus outdated. To trigger a fresh travis build, this pull request should be closed and re-opened.
Looks like this has many unaddressed comments. Added "Waiting for author" label.
@laanwj It looks like the author hasn't been very active on GitHub lately. I'm going to label this "Up for grabs" and close.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -52,6 +52,10 @@ def find_format_specifiers(s):
         percent = s.find('%', pos)
         if percent < 0:
             break
+        try:
+            specifiers.append(s[percent+1])
+        except:

@@ -52,6 +52,10 @@ def find_format_specifiers(s):
         percent = s.find('%', pos)
         if percent < 0:
             break
+        try:
+            specifiers.append(s[percent+1])
+        except:
comments.body: While sharing the vision of aiming for perfectionism, a proper "validation" of specifiers might be difficult, if going for more than a simple notification then I would also try to cover possible cases where the input data can be misinterpreted by missing a trailing space. I will think about a better while still easy solution and update the PR.

comments.body: translators accidentally like to sneak in a space after % as well, probably there's a solution to identify all of those errors. tbh I didn't think much about it recently
